raw_text:
Russia WTO talks 'make progress'
 
 Talks on Russia's proposed membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) have been "making good progress" say those behind the negotiations.
 
 But the chairman of the working party, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland, warned that there was "still a lot of work has to be done". His comments came as President George W Bush said the US backed Russian entry. But he said for Russia to make progress the government must "renew a commitment to democracy and the rule of law". His comments come three days before he is due to meet President Vladimir Putin.
 
 Russia has been waiting for a decade to join the WTO and hopes to finally become a member by early 2006. A decision could be reached in December, when the WTO's 148 current members gather for a summit in Hong Kong. That would allow an earliest date for membership of January 2006, if the Hong Kong summit gave its approval. While pinpointing several areas in which there are difficulties in the bilateral and multilateral work with Russia, the US said the meeting was "much more efficient than we've seen for some time". And Australia said it was "one of the best (meetings) we can recall in terms of substance". Mr Johannesson also said progress "on the bilateral market access side is accelerating". Sticking points to membership have included limits on foreign ownership in the telecommunications and life insurance businesses, as well as issues surrounding counterfeiting, piracy, and data protection. Some WTO members also dislike Russia's energy price subsidies, which competitors say give Russian businesses an unfair advantage.
llama3.2:1b: Russia's proposed membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is making progress, but there are still many challenges to be addressed.
Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland expressed concern that despite progress, more work needs to be done before Russia can join the WTO by early 2006.
The US backs Russian entry into the WTO, with President George W Bush stating it has been a "much more efficient" meeting than previous ones.
llama3.2:3b: Russia's proposed membership of the World Trade Organisation has been making progress in talks, but Ambassador Stefan Johannesson warns there is still much work to be done.
US President George W Bush supports Russia's entry, with a possible decision in December that could allow early 2006 membership if approved by WTO members.
gemma2:2b: Russia's WTO membership talks are progressing, with positive signs from both sides.
Despite the progress, there are still obstacles to overcome before a decision can be made by December 2005, including market access issues and concerns about energy subsidies.
The US supports Russia's entry but insists on continued commitment to democracy and rule of law.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas from the text: 
- Talks about Russia's membership of the World Trade Organization (WTO) have made progress.
- Ambassador Stefan Johannesson, chairman of the working party behind Russia's WTO talks, warned that there is "still a lot to be done".
- The US and other countries are backing Russian entry, with President Bush supporting it.
- A meeting between President Bush and Vladimir Putin is planned for December in Hong Kong.
- Progress has been made on bilateral market access issues.
- Russia has been waiting a decade to join the WTO.
- Some challenges remain in terms of foreign ownership in telecoms and life insurance businesses, counterfeiting, piracy, and data protection.
Some countries also dislike Russia's energy price subsidies.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Russia's proposal for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership has progressed satisfactorily but faces ongoing challenges including foreign ownership limits in telecommunications and life insurance, counterfeiting issues, piracy, data protection concerns, and energy price subsidies deemed unfair by some WTO members.
Russia aims to join the organization by early 2006 if a decision is reached before December's summit.
qwen2.5:3b:
Russia WTO talks 'make progress'
Despite "good progress," negotiations on Russia joining the World Trade Organisation (WTO) are not yet complete, with Iceland's ambassador warning that further work is needed.
US President George W Bush supports Russia's entry but demands reforms in democracy and rule of law.
Russia has been waiting ten years to join WTO; a decision could be made by December at WTO summit in Hong Kong, potentially allowing membership early 2006 if approved.
Issues include foreign ownership limits, counterfeiting, piracy, data protection, and unfair energy subsidies.
opencoder:1.5b: The President of the United States backed the entry into the world trade organization (WTO) signed a memorandum to reassure Russia that it would continue to operate effectively in the international marketplace.
The WTO's 148 current members gathered on a special summit in the hope of finding a better deal for the next few decades.
While there are some difficulties with the bilateral and multilateral work, it has been an effective means of progress since it allowed a more controlled entry into the market.
In terms of policy, however, the US said that meetings were more efficient than what was seen before.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and objective, capturing the main points of the text without adding or subtracting any information.
It provides a clear overview of the key ideas and details in the original text, making it easy to understand and compare different perspectives on the same topic.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Russia is negotiating its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) with Ambassador Stefan Johannesson from Iceland.
President George W Bush stated the US supported Russian membership but highlighted the need for a government commitment to democracy and the rule of law.
Russia aims to join by early 2006, potentially in December at the WTO summit in Hong Kong.
Despite efficient meetings so far, significant work remains.
Issues include foreign ownership of telecommunications and life insurance businesses, counterfeiting problems, data protection concerns, and energy price subsidies affecting Russian businesses.
tinyllama:1.1b: Russia WTO talks have been progressing, with the working party stating that there is still "a lot of work" to be done before making good progress in the negotiations.
President George W Bush has stated that for Russia to make progress in joining the WTO, it must renew its commitment to democracy and the rule of law.

While discussions on the bilateral market access side have been productive, a number of stakeholders remain opposed to certain issues, including restrictions on foreign ownership in telecommunications and life insurance businesses, as well as counterfeiting and data protection.
Some WTO members also dislike Russia's energy price subsidies.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The WTO Working Party on Russian Membership has reportedly been making "good progress," according to those involved in the talks.

However, Chairman of the Workshop, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland, expressed concern about the level of work left to be done by Russia, suggesting that there is still a lot of room for improvement and urged Moscow to commit itself wholeheartedly to democratic values and the rule of law.
President George W. Bush has also given his support to Russia's application for WTO membership, expressing hope that the process will be concluded within December.
However, Russian negotiators must renew their pledge to make progress in areas such as foreign ownership restrictions, counterfeiting, and price subsidies for energy production.
The Hong Kong summit is expected to approve a timeline for Russia's WTO application and potentially set an early date for its membership.

However, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson warned that there was still a lot of work to be done.
President George W. Bush said that the US backed Russian entry and that for Russia to make progress, they must renew their commitment to democracy and the rule of law.
Russia has been waiting ten years to join the WTO and hopes to become a member by early 2006.
The decision could be reached in December at the summit in Hong Kong, with an earliest date for membership in January 2006 if the Hong Kong summit gives its approval.
Progress on market access issues is accelerating, but there are still areas of difficulty in the bilateral and multilateral work with Russia.
Some WTO members object to Russian energy price subsidies which they believe give Russian businesses an unfair advantage.

However, the US supports Russian membership and has praised the meeting for being more efficient than usual.

Australia also sees progress in the bilateral market access side, while sticking points remain around telecommunications and life insurance businesses, as well as counterfeiting, piracy, and data protection.
The US is still concerned about limitations on foreign ownership in the two remaining industries.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Russia's potential WTO membership is making progress during ongoing talks, with Iceland's Ambassador Stefan Johannesson indicating substantial advancements.
However, he emphasized that extensive work remains to be done.
US President George W Bush endorsed Russian entry, stating it requires a renewed commitment to democracy and the rule of law.
This support comes ahead of his meeting with President Vladimir Putin.
Russia has been pursuing WTO membership for a decade, aiming for early 2006.
The decision could be finalized at the WTO's December summit in Hong Kong, potentially starting January 2006.

Key challenges include foreign ownership restrictions in telecommunications and insurance, counterfeiting, piracy, data protection, and concerns over energy price subsidies that some members believe unfairly benefit Russian businesses.
Despite these issues, the meetings have been characterized as highly efficient by both the US and Australia.
Progress is noted to be accelerating on the bilateral market access front, particularly in resolving foreign ownership limits and addressing counterfeiting, piracy, and data protection concerns.
